title: Python Programming Fundamentals
description: Learn the basics of Python programming through hands-on coding exercises. You'll start with simple output statements and progress through variables, data types, operators, and control flow.
narrative_context: You're learning Python to automate everyday tasks and analyze data. These fundamental skills will form the foundation for everything you build with Python - from web applications to data science projects.

learning_objectives.description: Recall Python syntax for print statements, variables, and basic operators
Explain how Python handles different data types and type conversion
Write Python programs that use variables, operators, and control flow
Debug Python code by identifying syntax and logic errors

content:
## Welcome to Python!

Python is one of the most popular programming languages in the world. It's known for being:

- **Easy to read** - Python uses indentation and simple syntax
- **Versatile** - Used for web development, data science, automation, and more
- **Beginner-friendly** - Great first programming language

In this project, you'll learn the fundamentals step by step.

epics.title: Getting Started
epics.description: Your first Python programs - learning to output text and use comments

learning_objectives.description: Recall the syntax for print() and comments

tasks.title: Hello World
tasks.description: Write your first Python program that displays a message
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Successfully use the print() function
- Display text output in the console

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Start with the absolute basics. Let the learner experiment and see immediate results.
discussion_prompts: What do you think print() does?
Why do we need quotes around text?
hints_to_give: Python uses print() to display output
Text needs to be wrapped in quotes

subtasks.title: Print a greeting
subtasks.description: Use the print() function to display 'Hello, World!'
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use print() function correctly
- Output contains 'Hello, World!'

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: This is their first program - celebrate the success! Explain each part.
hints_to_give: In Python, we use print() to show output
The full syntax is: print("Hello, World!")
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: print() is Python's built-in function for output. The text inside quotes is a 'string literal'. This simple program demonstrates the basic structure: function_name(argument).

subtasks.title: Print multiple lines
subtasks.description: Use multiple print() statements to display your name and a fun fact about yourself
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use at least 2 print() statements
- Display your name on one line
- Display a fact on another line

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Build on their success. Show that programs execute line by line, top to bottom.
hints_to_give: You can have multiple print() statements
Each print() creates a new line by default
Try: print("My name is...") then print("I like...")
common_mistakes: Putting everything in one print() without understanding newlines
Forgetting quotes on the second statement

tasks.title: Comments
tasks.description: Learn to write comments to document your code
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Understand single-line comments using #
- Know when and why to use comments

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Explain that comments are notes for humans, not instructions for the computer.
discussion_prompts: Why would we want to write notes in our code?
Who might read our comments later?
common_mistakes: Forgetting comments explain WHY, not just WHAT

subtasks.title: Add a comment
subtasks.description: Add a comment explaining what your code does, then print a message
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Include at least one comment starting with #
- The comment explains the code's purpose
- Code still runs and produces output

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Show that comments are ignored by Python. The learner should see that comments don't affect output.
hints_to_give: Everything after # on that line is ignored by Python
common_mistakes: Thinking comments will show in output
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Comments with # are single-line comments. Python ignores them completely, but they help humans understand the code's purpose.

epics.title: Variables and Data Types
epics.description: Learn to store and work with different types of data

learning_objectives.description: Explain the purpose of variables and different data types
Create variables and use them in expressions

tasks.title: Creating Variables
tasks.description: Learn to create variables to store information
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create variables with meaningful names
- Assign values to variables
- Use variables in print() statements

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Use the analogy of labeled boxes that hold values. Emphasize that variable names should be descriptive.
discussion_prompts: What would be a good name for a variable storing someone's age?
Why might 'x' be a poor variable name?

subtasks.title: Store and print a name
subtasks.description: Create a variable called 'name' with your name, then print it
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create a variable named 'name'
- Assign a string value
- Print the variable (not the literal text)

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Show the difference between printing a literal string vs. a variable. Variables don't need quotes when used.
hints_to_give: Use the variable in print: print(name)
Notice: no quotes around 'name' in print()
common_mistakes: Putting the variable name in quotes
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Variables store values for later use. The = sign is the assignment operator - it puts the value on the right into the variable on the left.

subtasks.title: Store a number
subtasks.description: Create a variable called 'age' with a number, then print a message using it
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create a variable with a numeric value (no quotes)
- Print the age in a sentence

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Highlight that numbers don't need quotes. Introduce the concept of different data types.
hints_to_give: You can combine strings and variables
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Python has different data types. Numbers (integers) are written without quotes. Strings (text) need quotes. Python keeps track of what type each variable holds.

tasks.title: Data Types
tasks.description: Understand the main data types in Python: strings, integers, floats, and booleans
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Identify different data types
- Use type() to check data types
- Understand when to use each type

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Use real-world examples for each type: names (strings), ages (integers), prices (floats), yes/no (booleans).
discussion_prompts: What type would you use for a price?
What type would you use for a true/false question?

subtasks.title: Check types
subtasks.description: Create variables of different types and use type() to check them
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create at least one string, one integer, one float, and one boolean
- Use type() to print each variable's type

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Let them discover what type() returns. Build intuition about types.
common_mistakes: Forgetting that floats have decimal points
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Python's four basic types: str (strings for text), int (integers for whole numbers), float (for decimals), bool (True/False for logic). type() is a built-in function that tells you a value's type.

epics.title: Operators and Expressions
epics.description: Learn to perform calculations and operations in Python

learning_objectives.description: Use arithmetic operators to perform calculations
Use comparison operators to compare values

tasks.title: Basic Math
tasks.description: Use Python as a calculator with arithmetic operators
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use +, -, *, / operators
- Store results in variables
- Print the results

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Start with simple calculations they can verify mentally. Build up to combining multiple operations.

subtasks.title: Calculate a sum
subtasks.description: Add two numbers together and print the result
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use the + operator
- Store result in a variable
- Print the result

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Simple and straightforward. Let them see Python do math.
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Python evaluates the expression 5 + 3 first, getting 8, then stores that value in the variable.

subtasks.title: Multiple operations
subtasks.description: Calculate the total cost of 3 items at $19.99 each, then print the result
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use multiplication
- Display the total cost

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: A practical example they can relate to. Introduce the concept of formulas in code.
common_mistakes: Using x for multiplication instead of *
Forgetting that floats give decimal results

tasks.title: Comparison Operators
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Understand that comparisons return True or False
- Use comparison operators correctly

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Explain that comparisons ask questions: 'Is 5 greater than 3?' Python answers True or False.
discussion_prompts: When would we need to compare values?

subtasks.title: Compare numbers
subtasks.description: Use comparison operators to compare two numbers, print the results
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use at least 2 different comparison operators
- Print the boolean results

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Show multiple comparisons. Build understanding that these will be crucial for making decisions in code.
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: Comparison operators return boolean values (True/False). == checks equality, != checks inequality. These are the foundation of conditional logic.

epics.title: Control Flow
epics.description: Make decisions in your code with if statements and loops

tasks.title: If Statements
tasks.description: Make decisions in code based on conditions
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Write if statements with proper indentation
- Use elif and else for multiple conditions

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Use real-world decision-making as an analogy: 'If it's raining, take an umbrella'.

subtasks.title: Check a condition
subtasks.description: Write an if statement that prints 'Adult' if age is 18 or over, otherwise prints 'Minor'
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create an age variable
- Use if/else to check the condition
- Print the appropriate message

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Emphasize the structure: if condition: (indented block). The colon and indentation are crucial.
hints_to_give: The next line must be indented
Use else: for the other case
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: if statements evaluate a condition. If True, the indented block runs. else provides an alternative when the condition is False. Indentation defines what code belongs to each block.

subtasks.title: Multiple conditions
subtasks.description: Write a program that grades a test score: A (90+), B (80-89), C (70-79), F (below 70)
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use if/elif/else chain
- Handle all four grade ranges
- Print the letter grade

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Build up from one condition at a time. Show how elif chains create multiple branches.
hints_to_give: Start with the highest grade first
score >= 90 for A, score >= 80 for B, etc.
common_mistakes: Forgetting that elif is one word, not else if
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: elif (else-if) allows multiple conditions. Python checks them in order and runs the first True block. Once a condition matches, it skips the rest.

tasks.title: For Loops
tasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use for loops with range()
- Iterate over a list of items

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Explain loops as automation: instead of writing print() 10 times, use a loop.
discussion_prompts: When would repeating code be useful?
What if you needed to do something 1000 times?

subtasks.title: Count with a loop
subtasks.description: Use a for loop to print the numbers 1 through 5
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Use for loop with range()
- Print numbers 1 to 5 (not 0 to 4)

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Introduce range() and how it generates sequences. Note that range starts at 0 by default.
hints_to_give: The second number is exclusive (not included)
common_mistakes: Forgetting the colon after for line
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: range(start, stop) generates numbers from start up to (but not including) stop. The loop variable (i) takes each value in turn.

subtasks.title: Loop through a list
subtasks.description: Create a list of 3 favorite foods and use a for loop to print each one
subtasks.acceptance_criteria:
- Create a list with []
- Use for loop to iterate
- Print each item

tutor_guidance.teaching_approach: Show that loops can iterate over any sequence, not just numbers.
common_mistakes: Using the list name instead of the loop variable
tutor_guidance.answer_rationale: for item in list: iterates through each element. The variable (food) holds the current item on each iteration. This is more Pythonic than using indices.
